title: De Blasio defends handling of mentally ill homeless in wake of brutal attacks
text:
The city has put additional outreach workers on the street in Chinatown, but will not make any immediate policy changes in response to the murders, Mayor Bill de Blasio said. | Hans Pennink/AP Photo De Blasio defends handling of mentally ill homeless in wake of brutal attacks

Mayor Bill de Blasio defended his administration’s handling of mentally ill people living on the street Tuesday, as police revealed that the man accused of beating four homeless men to death in Chinatown is also suspected of attacking another man a week earlier.

The brutal murders — allegedly committed by 24-year-old Randy Santos, who was also homeless — have raised questions about why he was allowed to remain on the street despite a slew of prior arrests. They have also raised questions about the effectiveness of the already-embattled ThriveNYC program — the $1 billion mental health initiative created by first lady Chirlane McCray.

Story Continued Below

De Blasio resisted calls to get more aggressive in removing mentally ill homeless people from the streets.

“A lot of people would like the easy solution — just anyone who seems to be a problem is removed and sent to a mental institution. That’s what happened in this state, in this country for decades and decades. It led to horrific outcomes for a lot of people,” de Blasio told reporters at a press conference in Queens.

“We don’t want to go back on that merry-go-round. We need to be really clear about that moment where someone is a danger to themselves or others, where they should be removed from the streets, where they should be compelled to get treatment, versus a situation where there are other tools to use,” he added. “You have to be careful about that, because we don’t have endless capacity to put people in mental institutions ... And because it’s a country of laws, that respects individual liberty.”

State legislation known as Kendra’s Law allows people to be committed to psychiatric treatment against their will under certain circumstances. It was used 2,500 times last year, de Blasio said.

Police Commissioner James O’Neill acknowledged cops struggle to decide when someone poses enough of a danger that they can be removed from the streets.

“It’s a difficult call,” he said. “Where do you draw the line?”

Santos had been arrested at least six times in the last two years — including for multiple random, violent assaults — and also had a number of additional sealed arrests, police said.

He’s now been linked to another attack against a homeless man a week before the Chinatown murders, NYPD Chief of Detectives Dermot Shea said Tuesday. A man sleeping on a bench along the West Side Highway woke up to find someone attacking him with a stick, and attempting to throw him over a railing into the Hudson River.

Police have surveillance video of Santos seven blocks away and believe he was behind the attack, Shea said.

“The current status quo is not working, and the completely hands off approach is not working,” said City Council Member Joe Borelli. “At some point, when there are people who have multiple arrests, when they’re posing a threat to others ... we have to be more aggressive in applying the maximum legal pressure.”

ThriveNYC has failed to make a dent in the population of seriously mentally ill people on the street, said Borelli, a Republican representing Staten Island.

“We believed the administration was seriously going to combat the kind of public mental illness that results in homelessness. That was expected from day one," he said. "It hasn’t been addressed.”

The city has put additional outreach workers on the street in Chinatown, but will not make any immediate policy changes in response to the murders, de Blasio said. “Once we get all the facts, we might see something we want to do differently, but right now the goal is to get every homeless person off the street,” he said.

De Blasio also condemned the heated anti-homeless rhetoric used just days after the murders by Queens residents fighting plans for a shelter in their neighborhood.

“I hope somebody’s going to burn the place down,” one woman said of the proposed shelter in a video that circulated on Twitter.

At the meeting to discuss a proposed men’s shelter in Glendale, hecklers interrupted a moment of silence for the four men bludgeoned to death on the street, the Queens Daily Eagle reported. Another woman called the homeless “drug addicts and sexual offenders” and said they “should be locked away forever and out of sight permanently,” according to the paper.

De Blasio vowed to press forward with plans for a shelter despite the vitriolic opposition.

“It’s entirely unacceptable,” he said. “These are human beings. You know, there’s a phrase, 'There but for the grace of God go I.' What we have to educate people about is the vast majority of people in shelters today are there because they simply couldn’t make ends meet ... There’s no place for that kind of rhetoric.”
description: De Blasio resisted calls to get more aggressive in removing mentally ill homeless people from the streets.
